displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because most of what we’re looking for is how you feel. Oh, I’m having nausea. No. I’m not having nausea. Oh, this was a cakewalk. Oh, my fingers aren’t numb. Huh, my counts, huh, you know, are fine. Things that we’re going to be testing. So then we can sort of compare what blood test and symptoms are for those who actually get the vitamin C versus those who don’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have a fifty-fifty chance that you’re going to get the real stuff. Huh, you know, there is some flexibility. They want you here at least twice a week. But you know, if you’re going to go on holiday or something, you know, we can switch it. Huh, so far we know that giving high doses of vitamin C is safe. Huh, we haven’t seen many real extra side effects. But we don’t know the end of the answer. Does it help with side effects? Does it help activity? Or is there no difference? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you would be potentially eligible for that. Huh, if you do a clinical trial, it does slow down a little bit when we get started. Okay? Huh, because we would first want to check your insurance company that they will pay for the clinical trial. You’re not on Medicare yet. You’re not sixty-five. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. Patient: Just with… Family Member: With what? Doctor: They’re PKs as you get blood draws every few hours. So you have to sit there though for a good all day long basically. Patient: I have to be like in the clinic or hospital? Doctor: Yeah. But this will have to be… Patient: This will be done here? Doctor: Those – a lot of those intense monitoring and everything has to be done downtown. Family Member: But is it K__ or is it H____? Doctor: K__. Gradually we can switch you back to here. Once those intense periods are done, the whatever you know close monitoring is done, then I would switch you back to coming here and getting the medication dispensed. Patient: Does is require an IV or anything like that? Doctor: It will. They’ll probably start an IV just to have it for blood draws.

Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles) Doctor: No, no, I think the hair loss is all pretty much even after one or two, so after we stop the hair grows back. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So, so, that does happen. The other thing to watch for is if there’s tingling or numbness, okay, typically in the fingertips and the toes. If that is happening, I will, you know we may have to make adjustments to the dose. What happens is we start everyone on one standard dose and then dial down, depending on how they’re tolerated. Okay, so, so I think like I told you, the first course pretty much is important because both you and I will find out how you’re going to tolerate. Patient: Right, well my my feet, you know even like right now, they’re a little tingly. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I - you know from sitting in the car for an hour coming up here and that’s - Doctor: Yeah, and the cold right now - Patient: And the cold and sitting - Doctor: And the other thing is as you lose your hair, since we’re doing this right in the middle of winter, you have to protect your head. Family Member: Yeah. Yes. Doctor: Because that’s a sudden change that your body in this cold will really have a tough time getting used to. Yes. Family Member: I had a question about if it does cause nausea (pause)

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We sort of made that be like uh a line in the sand so to speak, so- Patient: What about the PSMA, uh? Doctor: So that was going to be the next thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Uh, we, there’s going to be a trial that’s a multi-centered trial that coming on-line, but it’s going to be a while. Uh, right now I think the trial is still ongoing at Cornell. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s actually a group that would get you back to California. There’s a group at UCLA (laughs) Patient: And how does, what’s the effect of that when you get treated? I mean what is, what’s different about that? Would that, would that go after the growth in the lymph nodes? Doctor: Yes. So PSMA is a thing that’s on the surface of crossing cancer cells. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it’s an enzyme, which means uh we’re not really sure what it does but we are, we’re able to block its function with a with a small drug. Uh and what people actually here when we started doing it, uh people thought well that would be cool to take an image of the cancer-

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it looks like, you know, that’s always a concern with us giving the testosterone, the possibility it could make things worse. It sort of looks like it’s just a continuing monitor. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things are progressing along at a certain pace, and we haven’t really changed the much of that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Slow sort of speak with either thing that we tried. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Looking at the first scan we did when we first started. The scan we did after enzalutamide. So then we’re back at sort of like this. It sort of looks like we’re staying on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So things are still growing at a slow to moderate pace, I’d say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so yeah I, I, I’m always concerned about that but I don’t think it’s reflective of making it grow more.

Patient: I’ve been having it, doctor, I’ve been disappointed though uh when I put, two weeks after I put in there do not let anyone come and pick up my medication if it’s not me. Why would you still let somebody pay but they said it was another girl cuz C____ the young lady that said I do know – Doctor: Mmm. Patient: - said no it wasn’t us. It must have been the girl somebody new but she was at the office where they explained that to her. Doctor: Alright so I’ll you a new script then. Patient: But anyway… Doctor: And you’re gonna get it filled at H____? Patient: Oh yeah but anyway, but anyway uh Dr. B____ the, the, the I think he’s short. I can’t think of his name. Anyway, he told me to talk to him. It’s a Chinese guy that that that denied me, but his boss… Doctor: M____ Pharmacy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or where? Patient: His boss is the short guy. That’s who I’m waiting to talk to. I’m hoping he’ll be here today so that when I leave here today I can talk to him. Doctor: Okay. So we’ll give you the script and then you go there first see if they are willing to. Patient: Tell me what’s going on Dr. B____. That’s what I want to know. What is the – this is the call they’re sending everything

Patient: I mean it’s. Doctor: It’s worth the, let’s, let’s try it. Patient: Okay. I, I you know and according to my survey you know I mean it’s a decision we have to make together. You know? Doctor: It is. Patient: And I think I ask a lot of questions. Doctor: No. I think you do. Absolutely. Patient: You know? J___ will probably ask more. (Laughs) Doctor: As I expect her to. (Laughs) Patient: She’s my little warrior. Doctor: Huh. I know. Patient: You know? It was you know I, I can of expected it. I was worried about hearing that but you’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. Doctor: You’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. And you know we could always switch course elsewhere. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we gotta go on a different hunt. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: What you… Doctor: Well good. You’re otherwise feeling okay? You look like a million buck from the, I mean I feel like I haven’t seen you in ages because I haven’t seen you in ages. Patient: No I ain’t saw you either. (Laughs) Doctor: W____ will come in with the paperwork and then we’ll get you out of here. Patient: Okay fine. Doctor: Okay? Any questions? Patient: No. Doctor: No?

Patient: Okay. And the Xtandi is, I’m out of refills. So I don’t know if C or you? It was prescribed by her. I forgot to mention to her last time because I Doctor: And uh where do you get that filled at? Patient: Right here. They mail them to me, so I have two weeks left. Patient: No. Doctor: And you’ve already talked to (names person) Patient: No. I gave her everything this morning. She has all the paperwork. Doctor: Okay, do you need anything from me other than that? Patient: No, I don’t think so. Doctor: Well then next time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh the, I don’t know if they come back yet. I saw that… Patient: And I had a bone density done . And I sent that to her, I don’t know if you saw that? Doctor: Uh and G___ is what kind of doctor?

Patient: It, it it ain’t moved at all? Doctor: No. Patient: That’s good. Doctor: I’m very glad just like W___ that it’s not in your hip. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: You already say Dr. P___ a while ago do you remember that for your back. Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Can I absolutely guarantee that the back isn’t causing the hip? No,- Patient: No. Doctor: -but you don’t technically have back pain right there in that spot that we pointed out. Patient: That is correct. Doctor: So that’s good news. Okay. Patient: But I do have back pain but it’s coming from the Provenge because they told me –

Patient: Right. Doctor: And you know I’m always happy to consider stuff experimental- Patient: Right. Doctor: -but at this moment we don’t have one that is exactly like this. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right. And this is ready to go FDA, four pills a day, Patient: Okay. Doctor: that’s it. Just one time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um and it’s proven to help improve for you to live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: For folks just like you. Patient: Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: It seemed like the transcripts were voice to text so sometimes they didn't quite make sense but i did the best i could

displayed_text: Patient: Back home laughs]] Doctor: Yeah, they are. Patient: laughs]] Okay. Doctor: This is your script for the PSA level and I need to give you um the scan order and everything so we’ll this same thing in three months when you come back. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: Okay? And let me look into your XGEVA injection. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they have to show that either your nerves are not working, your, uh, legs are not working, something or the other before we Patient: I wonder why they ain’t working good. Doctor: Yeah. So, they will say, “Did you try a walker? Did you try a this or that?” Patient: I, I, uh got a cane. I had a walker. Doctor: Okay. Now, Patient: Then I got a, then I got Doctor: Then, you got to try it. I don’t see you using it. Patient: I got it down ‘cuz it don’t, it don’t really be working for me. You know what I’m sayin’? ‘Cuz all I do is when I stop, I lean on it, lean down on it. I’d settle for the one with the seat on it. Now see, that’s the one that, um, I gotta see, if, if you can, can you see when the next time I can get one? The one with the seat on it? Doctor: The walker with the seat? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’ll give you script for that to take…

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Alright I was wondering if uh… Patient: How about the CAT scan? Doctor: CAT scan I just called them. Patient: Sure. Doctor: They’re still loading the images. So they said they’ll let me know in a few minutes once it’s ready. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay let me try and I’m going to… Patient: Take a look. Doctor: Did they put it in yet? Family Member: No. Doctor: Let me at least have it uploaded. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s in a location which is classical and typical for where prostate cancer can typically spread. Patient: Okay then that’s - where is it? Where did you say it went? Doctor: I have to remind myself which side it’s on. It’s on the abdominal - it’s in the abdomen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s too deep to feel, so it’s internal, inside the abdomen. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then.
